skills.name: Use the prime factor decomposition of a number to calculate factors
Use the prime factor decomposition of a number to calculate related numbers

explanations.A: Not Quite! I think you have written 10 as 5² which isn't correct. Think about how we can put the prime factors of 10 into our calculation.
explanations.B: Nearly! Have a check of all of your numbers again - are they all prime numbers? How can we make them all prime numbers?
explanations.C: Not quite! In this calculation the product of prime factors of 420 have been multiplied by another 2 x 3 x 5 x 7, when we only need to multiply by 10. What are the prime factors of 10?
explanations.D: We need to multiply by 10, which is 5 × 2 in prime factors. That means we need to increase the power on the 2 and the 5 by one each.

explanations.A: We need to multiply 168 by 10 to get 1680. This is the same as multiplying by 5 × 2 in prime factor form, so we multiply the prime factor product by 5 and 2.
explanations.B: Close! This would indeed make 1680! You have recognised that you need to multiply 168's prime factors by 10. :) You just needed to split 10 into its prime factors as well.
explanations.C: Not quite! In this calculation the product of prime factors of 168 have been multiplied by another 2 x 3 x 7, when we only need to multiply by 10. What are the prime factors of 10?
explanations.D: Very close! It looks like you have understood that you need to multiply the prime factor product of 168 by the prime factor product of 10 :) However, the prime factor product of 10 is not 5². That would be 5x5, which is 25. Instead, the prime factor product of 10 is 5 x 2.

explanations.A: Not quite! Remember that 9 can be written as 3².
explanations.B: Not quite! I think you are forgetting that 3⁴ = 3 x 3 x 3 x 3. Is 3 a factor of 3⁴?
explanations.C: The number has been expressed as a product of its primes, so equals these prime numbers multiplied together: 3 ✕ 3 ✕ 3 ✕ 3 ✕ 5 ✕ 5 ✕ 7 ✕ 7. Any of the primes 3, 5 or 7 will be a factor of the number, meaning Tom is correct. Furthermore, any combination of some or all of the prime factors multiplied together will also be a factor of the number. This means 3 ✕ 3 = 9 will be a factor, and so Katie is also correct.
explanations.D: Not quite! At least one of them is correct. We can use the prime factorisation to tell us all the factors of a number. Any prime factor itself, or combination of prime factors will make a factor of the original number.

explanations.A:
Not Quite! The number has been expressed as a product of its primes, so equals these prime numbers multiplied together as follows: 2 ✕ 2 ✕ 3 ✕ 3 ✕ 3 ✕ 5 ✕ 5. 
If we express 8 as a product of its primes we get 2 ✕ 2 ✕ 2. This isn't contained in the prime factorisation above which means 8 will not be a factor of this number. Will 3 be a factor of this number?
explanations.B: The number has been expressed as a product of its primes, so equals these prime numbers multiplied together as follows: 2 ✕ 2 ✕ 3 ✕ 3 ✕ 3 ✕ 5 ✕ 5. Any of the primes 2, 3, 5 or 7 will be a factor of the number, meaning Paul is correct. However, Jo is effectively saying 2 ✕ 2 ✕ 2 is a factor, but the prime factorisation only contains 2 ✕ 2, which is not enough for 8 to be a factor of the number.
explanations.C: Not quite! The number has been expressed as a product of its primes, so equals these prime numbers multiplied together as follows: 2 ✕ 2 ✕ 3 ✕ 3 ✕ 3 ✕ 5 ✕ 5. If a number is to be a factor of this number then its products of primes must be included within 2 ✕ 2 ✕ 3 ✕ 3 ✕ 3 ✕ 5 ✕ 5. How can we write 8 as a product of primes? Is this included in 2 ✕ 2 ✕ 3 ✕ 3 ✕ 3 ✕ 5 ✕ 5?
explanations.D: Not quite! The number has been expressed as a product of its primes, so equals these prime numbers multiplied together as follows: 2 ✕ 2 ✕ 3 ✕ 3 ✕ 3 ✕ 5 ✕ 5. If a number is to be a factor of this number then its products of primes must be included within 2 ✕ 2 ✕ 3 ✕ 3 ✕ 3 ✕ 5 ✕ 5. Will 3 be a factor of this number? How can we write 8 as a product of primes? Is this included in 2 ✕ 2 ✕ 3 ✕ 3 ✕ 3 ✕ 5 ✕ 5?

explanations.A: Not quite! Remember, 5² = 5 ✕ 5, not 5 ✕ 2. Expressing 75 as a product of primes will help you determine if 75 is a factor of this number or not.
explanations.B: The number has been expressed as a product of its primes, so equals these prime numbers multiplied together: 3 ✕ 3 ✕ 3 ✕ 3 ✕ 5 ✕ 5 ✕ 7 ✕ 7. Any of the primes 3, 5 or 7 will be a factor of the number, and any combination of some or all of the prime factors multiplied together will also be a factor of the number. Tom is incorrect because 10 = 2 ✕ 5, and 2 is not a factor, meaning 10 cannot be either. The number 75 = 5 ✕ 5 ✕ 3. All these appear as prime factors in the question, which means that 75 will be a factor of the number.
explanations.C: Close! Have another think about whether we can make 10 from the prime factors. Remember, 5² = 5 ✕ 5, not 5 ✕ 2.
explanations.D: Not quite, at least one person is correct. We can use the prime factorisation to tell us all the factors of a number. Any prime factor itself, or combination of prime factors will make a factor of the original number. This prime factorisation is equivalent to 3 ✕ 3 ✕ 3 ✕ 3 ✕ 5 ✕ 5 ✕ 7 ✕ 7. Do any of these numbers multiply together to make 10 or 75?

explanations.A: Not Quite! Remember, this prime factorisation equals 2 ✕ 2 ✕ 3 ✕ 3 ✕ 3 ✕ 5 ✕ 5. Can we make 6 with any combination of some or all of the prime factors multiplied together?
explanations.B: Not Quite! Remember, this prime factorisation equals 2 ✕ 2 ✕ 3 ✕ 3 ✕ 3 ✕ 5 ✕ 5. Can we make 45 with any combination of some or all of the prime factors multiplied together?
explanations.C: The number has been expressed as a product of its primes, so equals these prime numbers multiplied together: 2 ✕ 2 ✕ 3 ✕ 3 ✕ 3 ✕ 5 ✕ 5. Any of the primes 2, 3, 5 or 7 will be a factor of the number, and any combination of some or all of the prime factors multiplied together will also be a factor of the number. Jo is correct because 6 = 2 ✕ 3, and 2 and 3 appear in the prime factorisation. Paul is also correct because 45 expressed as a product of its primes = 5 ✕ 3 ✕ 3. Since all these appear as prime factors in the question too, this means that 45 will also be a factor of the number.
explanations.D: Not quite, at least one person is correct. We can use the prime factorisation to tell us all the factors of a number. Any prime factor itself, or combination of prime factors will make a factor of the original number. This prime factorisation is equivalent to 2 ✕ 2 ✕ 3 ✕ 3 ✕ 3 ✕ 5 ✕ 5. Do any of these numbers multiply together to make 6 or 45?

explanations.A: Tom is correct: the number does not have 2 anywhere in its prime factorisation, meaning it must be odd because all even numbers have 2 as a factor. Katie is wrong because the number clearly has factors other than 1 and itself, making it a non-prime.
explanations.B: Not quite! Remember, all even numbers have 2 as a factor, so have a look at the prime factorisation again here. Also have a think about what makes a number a prime number... can a prime number have lots of factors like this one does?
explanations.C: Nearly! Have a think about what makes a number a prime number... can a prime number have lots of factors like this one does?
explanations.D: Not quite! Remember, all even numbers have 2 as a factor, so have a look at the prime factorisation again here.

explanations.A: Not quite! We know that all even numbers have 2 as a factor, so have a look at the prime factorisation again here. Comparing the powers in Pauls calculation to the original will help you decide if Paul is correct.
explanations.B: Jo is incorrect: the number has 2 in its prime factorisation, meaning it must be even because all even numbers = 2 ✕ something. Paul is correct: this can be seen by comparing the powers. The number in the question has one more power of 3 than Paul’s number, which must mean it is 3 times bigger.
explanations.C: Not quite! We know that all even numbers have 2 as a factor, so have a look at the prime factorisation again . Comparing the powers in Pauls calculation to the original will help you decide if Paul is correct.
explanations.D: Not quite! At least one of them is correct. We know that all even numbers have 2 as a factor, so have a look at the prime factorisation again here. Comparing the powers in Pauls calculation to the original will help you decide if Paul is correct.

explanations.A: To work out 3A, multiply A by 3, to give 3 ✕ 3⁴ ✕ 5² ✕ 7². This means we now have an additional power of 3 to give 3⁵ ✕ 5² ✕ 7².
explanations.B: Be careful! We can write the prime factorisation in expanded form as: 3 ✕ 3 ✕ 3 ✕ 3 ✕ 5 ✕ 5 ✕ 7 ✕ 7. We just need to add another ' ✕ 3' onto it. I think you have added 3 lots of each of the prime factors on again.
explanations.C: Not quite. This answer multiplies each of the powers by 3, whereas we just need to add another ' ✕ 3' onto the prime factorisation.
explanations.D: Not quite! You have multiplied each of the prime factor values by 3 here. Remember, We can write the prime factorisation in expanded form as: 3 ✕ 3 ✕ 3 ✕ 3 ✕ 5 ✕ 5 ✕ 7 ✕ 7. We just need to add another ' ✕ 3' onto it

explanations.A: As we are expressing 10A as a product of its primes, we need to bear in mind that 10 = 2 ✕ 5. Now, to work out 10A, multiply A by 10, to give 10 ✕ 2³ ✕ 3³ ✕ 5² = 2 ✕ 5 ✕ 2³ ✕ 3³ ✕ 5². Tidying this up means that the power of the base numbers 2 and 5 will each increase by 1 to give 2⁴ ✕ 3³ ✕ 5³.
explanations.B: Nearly! You have the right idea, but I think you mistakenly multiplied by 10 as 5 ✕ 5 rather than 2 ✕ 5
explanations.C: Not quite! 10 ✕ 2³ is not the same as 20³. Writing 10 as 2 ✕ 5 will help when simplifying 10 ✕ 2³ ✕ 3³ ✕ 5².
explanations.D: Not quite! 10 ✕ 5² is not the same as 50³. Writing 10 as 2 ✕ 5 will help when simplifying 10 ✕ 2³ ✕ 3³ ✕ 5².
